metadata.title: CASE 278/04: Investigation Report on Pristina Airport FIDS Tender Irregularity
metadata.primary_source: United Nations Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo (UNMIK)

overview: The report investigates administrative irregularities in the procurement process for the Flat Information Display System (FIDS) at Pristina Airport, highlighting potential conflicts of interest and irregular tendering procedures.

applicable_laws.excerpt: Procurement Regulation applicable during the time of the investigation.

methodology.description: Review of procurement files and document analysis.
documents_reviewed: Notes of recommendation and justification for FIDS purchase

background.context: The Single Source Procurement for FIDS at Pristina Airport began on 2002-10-17, necessitated by the expansion of the Passenger Terminal Building. Vendor 1 was initially selected due to their previous provision, but due to an inability to handle cabling, a subsequent tender was held, won by Vendor 2.
timeline: 2002-12-13: Capital Expenditure approved, and contract signed.
2004-03-01;2004-03-31: Tender for FIDS cabling commenced, Vendor 2 won.

allegations.description: An official from a non-Airport related company was involved in recommending and justifying procurement decisions.
allegations.findings: The Vendor 2 Representative, not employed by the Airport, drafted two notes recommending FIDS purchase.

allegations.description: Vendor 2 Representative was involved in preparing and subsequently participating in the FIDS cabling tender.
allegations.findings: This involvement provided Vendor 2 a competitive advantage, acknowledged by the Vendor 2 Representative.

findings: Unauthorized individuals' involvement in procurement recommendations.
Unclear reasons for Vendor 1 not completing the FIDS cabling.
Vendor 2's advantage in the tender process due to prior involvement.
PEAP official did not fulfill management requirements for handling sensitive airport matters.

actions: PEAP Official should be replaced by a highly qualified manager meeting international management standards.
Airport staff responsible for procurement should receive adequate training and adhere to Procurement Regulations.
Companies or agencies involved in procurement preparation should be excluded from related tenders.
